title: Erdős Problem #686: Ratios of Products of Consecutive Integers
description: Can every integer N ≥ 2 be written as ∏(m+i) / ∏(n+i) for some k ≥ 2 and m ≥ n + k? OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #686 from [Er79d] asks whether all integers N ≥ 2 can be expressed as ratios of products of consecutive integers. Products of k consecutive integers equal k! * C(n+k, k), connecting to factorials and binomial coefficients. Related to Problem #677.
overview.problemStatement: Can every integer N ≥ 2 be written as ∏_{i=1}^k (m+i) / ∏_{i=1}^k (n+i) for some k ≥ 2 and m ≥ n + k? The constraints ensure non-trivial non-overlapping ranges with ratio > 1. OPEN.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines consecutiveProduct, ratioExpression (over Q), IsRepresentable, Representable, and ErdosConjecture686. Structural properties (numerator > denominator, ratio > 1, monotonicity) and binomial connections are axiomatized. Examples verified via native_decide. Proved: erdos_686_statement (simp).
keyInsights: m ≥ n + k ensures non-overlapping ranges and ratio > 1
The ratio C(m+k,k)/C(n+k,k) must be an integer — subtle divisibility
For fixed n, k, the representable set is infinite (ratio increases with m)

sections.title: Part I: Consecutive Products
sections.summary: Defines consecutiveProduct(n,k). Axioms: factorial and binomial relations. Three native_decide examples.

sections.title: Part II: The Ratio Expression
sections.summary: Defines ratioExpression over Q and IsIntegerRatio divisibility predicate.

sections.title: Part III: The Representation Property
sections.summary: Defines IsRepresentable (k ≥ 2, m ≥ n+k, ratio = N), Representable, ErdosConjecture686.

sections.title: Part VIII: Summary
sections.summary: Proved: erdos_686_statement (simp), erdos_686_status (trivial). Problem remains OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #686 remains OPEN. The question is whether every integer N ≥ 2 can be expressed as a ratio of products of k consecutive integers with non-overlapping ranges. The problem connects to factorials, binomial coefficients, and divisibility.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would show a rich representation theorem for integers via consecutive products.
openQuestions: For fixed n, k, what integers are representable?
What is the minimal k needed for each N?
How does this relate to Problem 677?
